Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement & Imaging program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation. Professor Thomas Hermann of the University of California, San Diego, develops nano-sized, self-assembling sensors for biologically-active molecules (analytes) including toxins in the environment and metabolites in organisms. The sensors are made from biocompatible building blocks which self-assemble upon analyte detection by exploiting recognition principles encoded in natural nucleic acids. The design approach allows the construction of sensors that detect a variety of different analytes simultaneously. A signal is generated only if a threshold concentration is reached for all analytes at the same time. The sensors constitute a novel application of biological materials in nanotechnology which is a rapidly emerging field of research for medical devices and environmental monitoring. The broader impact of the work is related to the development of novel RNA-based nanosensors whose function relies on the self-assembly from short oligonucleotides, triggered by analyte recognition. Students involved in the research gain broad and interdisciplinary training in areas of materials and device development for biological and medical applications.

This research develops sensors for biologically-active analytes based on modular RNA nanostructures that contain several copies of an aptamer which self-assemble to a signaling configuration in a cooperative response to ligand binding. By coupling sensor RNA assembly with multivalent cooperative ligand binding, sensing devices are created with nonlinear dose response over a wide dynamic range. The design concept for the sensors is based on previously developed self-assembling RNA nanostructures, including double-stranded RNAs in the shape of a square or triangle. The RNA nanosensors capitalize on two unique properties of RNA nanostructures: their modular design, which facilitates the rapid iterative optimization of sensor constructs for a variety of ligands, and their self-assembly from short oligonucleotides in an all-or-nothing process. The nanostructures design provides the basis for nonlinear cooperativity of ligand binding at multiple recognition sites. Modular design facilitates the design of a wide variety of RNA nanosensors with up to 4 ligand recognition sites within a single construct, allowing the design of AND-gated as well as OR-gated sensors. The sensor signaling is dependent on either the simultaneous or exclusive presence of two different ligands. Self-assembly of the complete signaling-competent RNA nanosensor depends on ligand binding to all aptamer units and gives rise to cooperative recognition behavior of multiple binding sites. The novel RNA nanosensors are capable of nonlinear dose response over a wide dynamic range. The research is performed by graduate and undergraduate students who are trained in a diverse array of technical skills including nucleic acid biochemistry, fluorescence assays, cloning, and biochemical in vitro assay development. The graduate students involved in the research gain a broad and interdisciplinary training, which renders the project ideally suited for the Chemical Biology graduate track at UCSD. Professor Hermann continue outreach efforts by recruiting members of groups underrepresented in science through self-initiated and campus-supported programs and by outreach to local high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of the research project on Self-Assembling RNA Nanosensors was to develop nucleic acid building blocks that self-assemble to form defined structures at the nanometer scale (1 nm = 0.000001 mm) in response to detection of an analyte molecule. By attaching fluorescent dyes to the nucleic acid building blocks, a fluorescent signal readout would be achieved as a result of analyte recognition which drives self-assembly.

Over the initial course of the research, we concluded that the most versatile designs for such nanosensors emerge from a partition of tasks between building blocks that serve as architectural components and other building blocks that assume a function of selectively recognizing and binding analyte molecules. According to this principle, we conceived a modular blueprint for nanosensors containing a constant set of architectural joints which could be combined with a variety of modules for the recognition of different analytes. Based on these requirements, we concluded that these two different roles would ideally be served by RNA for the architectural joints and DNA modules for analyte recognition. RNA-DNA hybrid nano-architectures combine benefits arising from the diversity of folds available in autonomous RNA motifs and the straightforward chemical and structural modification of robust DNA building blocks. A significant portion of the project was then dedicated to develop a versatile kit of robust nanoshapes that self-assemble from RNA and DNA modules (Figure 1). As an important component for the discovery of self-assembling RNA-DNA nanoshapes, we developed a gel-based screening method that allowed the identification of stable nanostructures emerging from systematic combinations of DNA and RNA building blocks.

The partitioning of architectural and functional roles for RNA and DNA modules in the hybrid nanoshapes is a novel approach that provides a prototype for expanding chemical diversity and functionality of self-assembling nucleic acid nanomaterials for applications in molecular recognition, sensor and catalyst development as well as protein interaction studies. As a broader impact on the field, our system of self-assembling RNA-DNA hybrid nanoshapes provides an open platform for application and modification by a wide range of users who are not required to be experts in nucleic acid structure or nanotechnology.

With a platform for the design of hybrid nucleic acid nanoshapes in hand, we then designed and built RNA-DNA nanosensors that self-assemble dependent on ligand binding, according to the initial aim of the research project. As a first result, we obtained a nanosquare sensor whose assembly depends on the presence of adenosine monophosphate (AMP), a metabolite involved in many cellular processes (Figure 2). Recognition of the AMP analyte was achieved through inclusion of a DNA aptamer module whose ability for analyte binding depends on the concurrent formation of the RNA-DNA nanosquare structure. Labeling of nucleic acid modules of the nanosquare with fluorescent dyes furnished a nanosensor that reports presence of AMP analyte through a fluorescent signal. The AMP nanosquare sensor serves as a general blueprint for the design and construction of nanosensors for other analyte molecules in future research.

Broader impacts of the research project include training for 2 graduate and 2 undergraduate students, among them one individual from an underrepresented minority. The URM student secured an Undergraduate Summer Research Fellowship sponsored by the Division of Physical Sciences at UC San Diego to continue research in the summer of 2019, based on preliminary data generated by the student during work on the NSF-funded research. The project resulted in the completion of one Masters thesis, partial contributions to a PhD thesis, one invention disclosure for a future patent filing (on sensors based on RNA-DNA hybrid nanoshapes), one published manuscript (on the development of RNA-DNA hybrid nanoshapes) and a second manuscript in preparation (on the AMP nanosensor).
